Description: Small Nile silt pottery jar coated with a red slip with black top and well burnished; small flat base, ovoid body with simple rim. Incised Y-shaped potmark on side, made post-firing, filled with white chalk in modern times.
Curator's comments: Black top red ware B75b/c in Petrie’s Corpus of Prehistoric Pottery (1921). Marked B101 on side. Grave B101 was the richest grave at the site and contained 19 varieties of fine pottery and many other interesting objects, the majority of which went to the Ashmolean Museum. For discussion of grave see W.M.F Petrie and A.C. Mace, Diospolis Parva, London (1901), p. 33, pl. v, where this pot is illustrated. Another small jar from this grave had a similar potmark.
